Like the first game, Half-Life 2 is an FPS revered not primarily for its gameplay, but for its presentation first and foremost. The structure of the game with its dialogue (which would be in cutscenes in modern day games, here you retain control over your character), characters, scripted events, and world building. In these regards it's a step up over its predecessor.

It's also a bit of a step up with its "puzzle" gameplay, which is really solving practical puzzles often with the aid of physics. The physics emphasis is greater in Half-Life 2 as it's a technological showcase in that regard, although these "puzzles" overall aren't the best of their kind.

As an actual FPS, Half-Life 2 largely omits the low resource, more survival oriented portions of the first game, and has vehicle sections instead. Both games have a bit more gameplay variety than the average shooter, with Half-Life 2 having claustrophobic CQB, larger scale outdoor gunfights, gunfights with allies so it's not just you, vehicle sections, some verticality. Again it isn't top tier in its diversity here, where Unreal is crowned, but it is adequate.

But compared to the first game, Half-Life 2 makes sacrifices to weapon diversity and most of all enemy diversity. For weapon diversity, Half-Life 2 is just average although one piece of equipment really aids it here, and that's the Gravity Gun being one of the coolest FPS weapon inventions ever. It lacks the more alien or higher tech Sci-Fi weapon design beyond this, although the first game's Hive-Hand is quite useless so not much is lost there. The trip mines were also quite useless. The satchel charges might be nice but aren't a requirement. 

And unlike the first game, every weapon retains some degree of usefulness here. The crowbar is always good against headcrabs, the pistol is always good for weaker enemies where you want to conserve ammo due to the SMG's inaccuracy. Every weapon has its use here, even if weapon design isn't brilliant overall.

A bit more cleverness went into the level design of the first game. Route Kanal has some questionable, useless areas, Half-Life was weak when it came to having secret areas/pickups on levels but Half-Life 2 doesn't even try here, there's no real brilliance in any of its level design and NPCs can sometimes struggle to navigate it.

The levels are also artistically outdated. Half-Life 2 is mostly set in outdoor locations but there are often very obvious voids in out of bound areas, or very obvious low quality filler models and textures just outside of the playable area. The outdoor maps never feel like real places and instead they always feel like old FPS video game maps, a weakness Half-Life doesn't have. Thankfully Cinematic Mod remedies this for Half-Life 2.

As everybody knows by now, Half-Life 2 and Source Engine in general retains the awkward, clunky slidey movement from GoldSource, but you're even floatier now. The lack of movement precision and responsiveness along with the ability to get stuck on light physics objects ensures that Half-Life 2 gameplay never flows particularly smoothly. You're slipping and sliding around and engaging in overall mediocre combat design.

Ultimately this is a solid game that, like its predecessor, is overrated considering the most loved thing about it is really its presentation. But it does craft a cool dystopian future with memorable characters, the Gravity Gun, and some fun physics related gameplay even if it never reaches the brilliance of some later games in this regard (like FEAR, Dark Messiah, and Crysis). 

Episode 1 is more of the same from Half-Life 2, a necessary expansion to the story with no gameplay improvements or decline. Episode 2 has slightly better combat encounters and introduces Hunters and Advisors which are nice to have.

I highly recommend anyone playing this game, first time or no, to use MMod 1.3 + Cinematic Mod 2013. This merge keeps the unwanted Cinematic Mod features out of the game and keeps its excellent graphics and artistic level design improvements, and MMod makes undeniably superior gameplay enhancements and is very configurable.

[h3]Strengths[/h3]
[list]
[*]Highly physics enabled world

[*]Interesting dystopian future setting with some memorable characters

[*]The Gravity Gun is one of the coolest weapons ever designed

[*]AI is advanced, albeit held back a bit too much

[*]Moderately diverse gameplay for an FPS

[*]Super moddable with some incredible mods, plus strong options configuration and a powerful console/terminal
[/list]

[h3]Weaknesses[/h3]
[list]
[*]Floaty, slidey movement doesn't feel good and lacks precision especially since you can get stuck on light physics objects, ladders are unreliable as is jumping out of water

[*]Extremely clunky vehicle sections that drag on for too long

[*]Enemy variety is lacking, even compared to the first game which isn't excellent here

[*]Weapon diversity is lacking overall

[*]Weapon switching was always unnecessarily clunky with its two-step process design. It only binds weapons to the 1-5 keys so you will have many weapons bound to one key. To switch, you press the key up to several times depending on the weapon you want to select, and then press LMB, opposed to the classic "press one key to equip a weapon" or weapon wheel designs which are much faster and more efficient.

[*]Player weapon accuracy is too poor considering how aimbotty and spongey Combine are, the lack of good cover shooter mechanics for those sections (leaning, iron sights), and the lack of any skill curve and creative design to weapons besides the gravity gun. Just pray and spray. Not unlike the first game though weapons are even less accurate here, further cementing Half-Life 2's FPS gameplay as just mediocre.

[*]Weapons feel ineffectual due to no recoil (fake recoil, no actual change in dispersion or muzzle climb when spamming the two full auto guns) and bullet spongey enemies who are not reactive to shots. You'll just be mag dumping them with the SMG or even pulse rifle while they stand there taking it, not trying to avoid your shots and not flinching or reacting to them in any meaningful way. Compare this to actual challenging battles with responsive guns and enemies in games like Unreal and Doom and Quake and even Turok 2, and it's really bad.

[*]Frag grenade throwing arc is awkward and not ideal

[*]Gravity Gun can't be used to force open doors

[*]The AI is better than it appears in-game due to some restrictions which make the game too easy

[*]AI, especially Combine, will sometimes brain fart at close range and not do anything, and their movement in combat is extremely limited. They always rush you making them very predictable, and they generally don't care to take cover. They will stand out in the open hosing you down while being hosed down, not really reacting to your shots.

[*]Combine AI is grenade spammy to the point where they just frag themselves and take care of much of the work for you

[*]Level design is weak in detail and sorely lacking in secrets and never achieves brilliance. You always feel like you're in dated video game maps rather than real places, unlike the first game.

[*]Maps appear visually unfinished with obvious voids or throwaway textures and models right outside of the playable area (fixed by Cinematic Mod)

[*]Still encourages some degree of cover shooting, even if not as much as the first game, yet has no leaning or iron sights

[*]Surround spatialization is bad and uneven

[*]Long in-game loading times

[*]Obviously a minor complaint but breakable crates not containing pickups are totally empty, whereas in the first game they at least had junk items/props in them
[/list]

One of the best games in history, hands down. The mechanics are flawless, as well as the gameplay; had to find better FPS mechanics out there; i dare you to find another game that combines FPS with action and platforming as flawlessly as this game.   

The graphics are still considered good even by modern standards, as well as the physics.  Considering this game basically revolutionized game physics...yeah. its aged well.

But even without all of that stuff, without any frills....its the story.  1984 esque, the HL2 story is incredible, to say the least.  It sucks you in like few other games can dare to do, up there with Zelda.  Rarely does a game universe literally drop me inside of it.  I have laughed, cried, gasped, jumped, every emotion possible while playing HL2 and its related games.   Simply astounding that a game can make me feel this way, and I doubt few other games will ever compare.

As I said, up there with Zelda, if not tied.  Buy it, for the story. You wont regrett it.

Following upon the foundation left by the great game Half-Life (or Half-Life: Source), once again you take up the mantel of Gordon Freeman, and once again are the hounds of hell set upon you.

This time however, things have changed, your horizons have broadened, and you are no longer caged within a maze of labs and passageways. In this sequel epic, you take the fight to the streets, across the landscape and to military strongpoints.

The gameplay is fantastic, its updated but its core remains functional; as well, the game remains true to the original but brings in plenty of new appeal and playstyle. Truth be told, this game does justice to the hype it's associated with.

This game, is utterly fantastic.

The epitome of the perfect modern FPS.

With visuals that still stand up, AI smarter then your average CoD (They even move to face you when their talking to you, CoD doesn't have that!) some really memorable moments, high adrenaline action, some nice vehicle sections - This game has it all.

The story picks up after the first Half Life Trilogy, Gordon has been reawakened by the ever mysterious G-Man and Gordon is needed once again to help save everyone.

Through City 17 all the way up the Citiadel the story is tight, and the action and gameplay fun. 

For me, there was never a moment that I was bored.

And similar to HL1 the puzzles were difficult, but not too difficult because of Valve and how they place objects and light and other entites in relation to eachother that subtely cue you in.

Overall, the perfect modern shooter that holds up 8 years later.

Первая часть этой серии для меня, в юности, стала одной из первых игр на моем компъюктере. Тогда, на одном из уровней лаборатории Black Mesa я застрял и так и не прошел дальше до конца, но несмотря на это, я очень любил пройденый участок, особенно навсегда запомнился первый час игры. 
До второй части я добрался уже немного повзрослев, в начале 2010х. Это игра стала одной из первых и самых ярких в начале моей эпохи открытия ШПД интернета. Несмотря на то, что прохождение было единственным, непередаваемая атмосфера и эмоции, два незабываемых финала, остались в памяти навсегда. К примеру ночной прорыв через тюрьму под саунд Мэрлина Мэнсона, пик любви к которому пришелся на это время и огромное множество других моментов, по сути вся игра.

Сам Фримен - не знаю как по авторскому замыслу, но мне лично видится простым обывателем, попавшим в обстоятельства, которые по своему значению значительно превосходят уровень его личности. С одной стороны, это даже редкое достоинство в наше время - ГГ "маленький человек", всего-лишь невероятно живучий ботан-лаборант, успешно прошедший через все испытания. Это и его молчаливость позволяет среднему игроку легче вжится в его шкуру или по краней мере сопереживать.

Это была настоящая любовь. Как одна из первых, она навсегда останется в моем сердце. Аминь.

Half Life 2 always seemed like an interesting game to me, however I never actually spent time to play it fully because I always got bored somehow. I felt that the game was just a engine tech demo, but thats what Lost Coast was for.

I'm actually glad I played through it finally. The story is interesting but not enough for me to actually care about it.

The gameplay is almost standard FPS, but takes a different approach and instead of being a generic run and gun shooter, you can use objects in the environments to make intresting kills. Also there is no regenerating health, well, aside from when you get poisoned by a posionous headcrab. Forcing you to not just run into and get hurt carelessly because you need to find health packs to recover.

The game environment is interesting because every now and then, instead of just going guns blazing through the entire game, you have to solve puzzles, which is the best way I could describe, to progress through certain parts of the game. This itself makes the game interesting enough to play it because the puzzles aren't challenge and require the use of the engine's physics. It's sort of fun.

The game's graphics haven't changes that much, aside from the source engine's updates giving it motion blur and some bloom. It still has really great graphics and runs really smooth without blowing up your computer. Still probably the best facial animations and graphics for its time.

I would recommend this game to anyone that has a Steam and to play this game at least once.
